subject: Home & DIY
title: Japan's High-Tech Toilet Culture
description: Learn Japan's High-Tech Toilet Culture in one minute.

hook.text: Japanese toilets have heated seats, bidets, air dryers, deodorizers, and sound effects. Over 80% of homes have one.

buildup.text: TOTO launched the Washlet in 1980. It sprays warm water, then warm air, removing the need for toilet paper.

discovery.text: The 'sound princess' plays flushing sounds for privacy. It was invented to stop people from flushing just for noise.

twist.text: Some models analyze urine for blood sugar and hydration, sending data to your phone. The toilet becomes a lab.

climax.text: Japanese toilets cut paper use 70%. Globally, toilet paper needs 27,000 trees dailyâ€”bidets could save forests.

punchline.text: Japan turned the toilet into a health care device.

quiz.question: What does the Japanese 'Otohime' (sound princess) device do?
options: It plays flushing sounds so users don't wastefully flush for noise
It plays calming music to reduce bathroom anxiety
It alerts when the toilet needs cleaning or maintenance
